text:
I'm joined exclusively by the leader of
Venezuela's Parliament which is

controlled by the opposition who your
vote has welcomed can you explain to us

how likely is it that president Maduro
will succeed in rewriting the

Constitution well listen a when week ago
we have a a huge and beautiful
demonstration from Venezuelan people

7,500,000 Venezuelans go to the street
in a very peaceful way in order to cast

a vote to say to Maduro government and
to the world that we don't want and a

constitutional assembly called
unilateral by Maduro so what we want

right now in Venezuela is very simple
but very deep we want free elections

according to the current constitutions
and what we want is that Maduro has to

respect the current constitution Maduro
is out of the Constitution right now and

the whole world and the whole world as
well and people is pushing him in order

to follow the rule of law the check and
balance and the values of democracy in

Venezuela it seemed to me that while
Hugo Chavez his predecessor was able to

rule with a certain kind of populist
charm with a lot of oil money those in

those days oil prices were high Maduro
has ruled much more using force using

the army are you worried that there
could be some kind of an almost civil

war like atmosphere developing in
Venezuela well I don't think that we are

close to a civil war in Venezuela
because a single words supposed to have

to equal or more or less equal bands
that is not the case in Venezuela what

we want to Venezuela what we have in
Venezuela right now is the whole country

behold democratic people in Venezuela
which is 90% of the population against a

minority who is in power right now and
it has no respect for the law has no

respect for the economy has no respect
for human rights so there is no divided

society Venezuela right now and it was
when Chavez was alive things are changed

in Venezuela dramatically what we have
right now is that the whole country

looking for democracy looking for an
open economy looking for social justice

and this is right now what maguro want
to stop in order to be in power all the

time that he can to be in power without
no rules and without no no no control

over over the over power what would you
like to see from the United States and

specifically from Donald Trump well we
have been calling to the international

community not only the United States
Latin American European Union the

Vatican the United States
behold the McCleary community in the

world and and we are calling for this
week which is crucial for Venezuela in

order to go with us pushing Maduro in
order to stop the Constitutional

Assembly in order to stop the
Constitutional Assembly in order to open

and it's paid for a real and deep
negotiation with the participation of

the international community and and and
and to build a real agreement in which

we can go to the people in order to ask
for a new government a new even a new

Parliament whatever it means to go to
real elections in Venezuela and and to

to go out to this crisis to this
violence that we are living right now

one of the tragedies that I've been
watching is that you have millions of

Venezuelans of maybe tens of thousands
at least hundreds of thousands fleeing

and and you have the strange example
Venezuelans migrating to other countries

I say strange because as you know for
many many decades it was people from all

over Latin America who would who would
flee their countries and come to

Venezuela they would flee a bad
oppressive or populist regimes from

other countries and come to Venezuela
and it's now Venezuelans leaving do you

worry that the economy is in such bad
shape at this point that it's in a kind

of free fall yeah what are you telling
it's real very important because

Venezuela is not only a Venezuelan
problem right now it goes abroad our

borders and it's a regional problem we
have almost half a million Venezuelan

people in Colombia in the case for
example of Florida in the election that

we made less last Sunday almost a 300
thousand a Venezuelan boat there were

both in Venezuelan people all over three
hundred cities all over the world and we

we have become unfortunately a country
that is expelling out Venezuelans to

other countries and this is part of the
the theme that we are not only a

regional problem but a global problem
and we need the help to other

democracies in order to change where we
are living right now in Venezuela and to

become know a second Cuba but a mother
country open in a democratic way with

very social justice and with opportunity
for all
